RECURRENT ATAXIA: may be on background of slowly progressive ataxia

Etiology

Typical Presentation

Episodic Ataxia, Type I

AD inheritance, 5-7 yo at onset, attacks 10 min-6 hours, myokymia in hands between attacks. Genetic testing commercially available. Acetazolamide reduces attacks.

Episodic Ataxia, Type II

AD inheritance, onset late childhood/ adolescence, attacks last hours, unable to maintain posture, vomiting. CACNA1A gene testing commercially available. Acetazolamide reduces attacks.

Hartnup Disease

Slow development, photosensitive pellagra-like rash, episodes of ataxia, +/- nystagmus, and mood changes to encephalopathy. Increased tone and DTRs. Episodes of worsening due to stress or infection. Aminoaciduria. Treat with niacin.

MSUD (Intermittent)

Irritability, progressive lethargy, attacks provoked by infxn, surgery or protein meal, onset 5 mo-2 yo. Aminoaciduria. Diet: arginine, benzoate and alpha-ketoacids.

Pyruvate Dehydrogenase Deficiency

Presents after 3 yrs, episodes of ataxia, dysarthria, possible with weakness and lethargy, may be spontaneous or provoked by infection, stress or high-carbohydrate meal, lasts hrs to wks. Elevated CSF lactate, skin biopsy for dx (although females may have false negative due to mosaicism). Treat with ketogenic diet and possibly CoQ10, carnitine, Vit E and C, alpha lipoic acid.

Glut-1 Deficiency Syndrome

+/- H/o seizures and encephalopathy, may occur following a fast, with accompanying lethargy, hypotonia and weakness. CSF glucose <40 mg/dL. Treat with ketogenic diet and possibly CoQ10, carnitine, Vit E and C, alpha lipoic acid.

Migraine

Typically, with other migrainous features. Treat as for classic migraine.

Pseudoataxia (epileptic)

Sudden onset with associated confusion, no nystagmus. EEG suggestive. Treat with AEDs.

Work-up for Cerebellar Dysfunction

  • Acute:
    • CT scan, Utox, CMP
    • Consider MRI/MRA if concern for stroke or vascular lesion
    • Consider LP if encephalopathic and neg scan, or suspect infectious or inflammatory etiology
    • MIBG scan, urine HVA and VMA, and chest/abd/pelvis CT +/- contrast if suspect paraneoplastic (such as opsoclonus myoclonus ataxia secondary to neuroblastoma), LP and serum paraneoplastic panels
  • Recurrent
    • MRI, MRA, MRS
    • Consider LP for CSF glucose if MRI normal
    • Additional genetic and metabolic testing based on results of above and clinical features
  • Chronic
    • MRI +/- MRA, MRS
    • Vitamin E level
    • Consider LP pending MRI result, to check glucose, OCB and IgG index, lactate and pyruvate
    • Additional genetic and metabolic work-up based on results of above and clinical features

Recall that many SCAs (AD cerebellar ataxias), Fragile X, and Friedreich Ataxia are repeat expansion diseases and will NOT be evaluated on WES..

Dystonia

Dystonia

  • An abnormal twisting posture of one or more body part caused by the contraction of muscles which contract and extend a joint at the same time.
  • Most children with dystonia are quite strong in the dystonic limbs.
  • It is usually increased by action (such as writing, walking or running), with stress, mental activities but may also be present at rest when severe.
  • Can be seen with one specific e.g. writer‚Äôs cramp
  • Sensory trick: something a person does to help improve or resolve the dystonia like touching the extremity, putting a popsicle stick in mouth (example of a sensory trick in a child who had neck dystonia)

Dystonia can be a primary disorder or a secondary. Primary dystonias are typically genetic disorders that can present at characteristic ages across the lifespan. Secondary dystonia results from underlying brain disease, injury or medication usage.

Treatment

Goal: decrease dystonia enough to improve motor control without causing worsening secretions, further impaired swallowing, increased weakness or excessive sedation.

Often children are on multiple medications for dystonia and also receiving injections of botulinum toxin and/or phenol.

  • Trihexyphenidyl (Artane) titration:

Week 1: 0.05 mg/kg BID

Week 2: 0.05 mg/kg TID

Week 3: 0.1 mg/kg TID

Week 4: 0.15 mg/kg TID

Week 5: 0.2 mg/kg TID

Weeks 6 & on: 0.25 mg/kg TID

If side effects occur, try slowing down the titration. Can take many weeks to months for benefit to be seen. Consider keeping patients on medication for up to 6 months to evaluate for benefit.

Side Effects: mydriasis, blurred vision, dry mouth, urinary retention, constipation, and rarely dizziness or slowed cognition.

‚Ä¢ Baclofen is a muscle relaxant medication but also works in the brain to reduce abnormal signals in the basal ganglia and spinal cord. Potential side effects: sedation, trunk and head muscle weakness, worsened swallowing

‚Ä¢ Clonazepam (Klonopin) and Diazepam (Valium) are benzodiazepines. Potential side effects: sedation, irritability, increased secretions

‚Ä¢ Carbidopa-Levodopa (Sinemet) is a dopamine precursor. Potential side effects: nausea and vomiting, sedation, constipation, light-headedness

Titration example (refer to weight-based dosing in the medication table at the end of the dystonia pathway table and round to the nearest quarter tab, liquid also available; the ‚ÄúAbnormal Movement‚Äù Order Set in Epic has weight-based Sinemet titration orders)

Possible Sinemet Side Effects: nausea, light-headedness, sedation, constipation, abnormal dreams

Take with food. For persistent nausea, add carbidopa (Lodosyn) at 12.5 to 25 mg TID with each carbidopa/levodopa dose.

‚Ä¢ Oxcarbazepine (Trileptal) is a seizure medication which acts at sodium channels in the brain. Potential side effects: sedation, lowers serum sodium, stomach upset, rash

‚Ä¢ Levetiracetam (Keppra) is a seizure medication. Potential side effects: irritability, sleepiness or insomnia

‚Ä¢ Phenobarbital is a barbiturate seizure medication, Potential side effects: sedation, elevated liver enzymes

‚Ä¢ Valproic acid (Depakene, Depakote) is a seizure medication. Potential side effects: sedation, tremor, weight gain, potential for liver enzymes, pancreatitis, anemia and platelet dysfunction

‚Ä¢ Tetrabenazine (Xenazine) is a dopamine-depleting medication. Potential side effects: drowsiness, depression, parkinsonism (slow movements, rigid muscles)

‚Ä¢ Sertraline (Zoloft) is a specific-serotonin reuptake inhibitor. Potential side effects: insomnia or sedation, upset stomach, mania, suicidality

Muscle Injections:

‚Ä¢ Botulinum toxin (Botox): this toxin weakens the connection between the nerve and the muscle, thereby weakening the muscle. There is benefit in certain types of dystonia, with only minimal weakening of the muscle. The goal of injections of botulinum toxin is to reduce the symptoms of dystonia, without causing significant muscle weakness. Toxin injections usually need to be repeated every 3 to 6 months. In younger children, the procedure may require sedation or anesthesia

‚Ä¢ Phenol: this medication is stronger than botulinum toxin and is often used for larger muscle groups in the legs. It is quite painful when injected and therefore is only done under anesthesia. This may be used in combination with botulinum toxin injections.

Surgical Options (for refractory cases):

‚Ä¢ Intrathecal Baclofen Pump: this infuses baclofen directly onto the spinal cord through a catheter implanted underneath the skin which is connected to a pump the size of a hockey puck placed in the abdomen. It does not have the side effect of sleepiness that high doses of oral baclofen may have. Typically, it works much better for spasticity rather than dystonia, but when there is a combined picture, doing an intrathecal baclofen test dose where a small dose of baclofen is infused either once (with a spinal tap) or continuously (with a catheter) and the tone is then reassessed over the next several hours to evaluate for a response.

‚Ä¢ Deep Brain Stimulation Surgery: this surgery implants electrodes into the brain to interfere with the inappropriate basal ganglia signals electrically (rather than chemically as medications do). The electrodes are connected via a wire implanted underneath the skin to a brain pacemaker placed in the chest. The pacemaker is programmed over the course of weeks to months to achieve the best effect on dystonia. Works best for mobile dystonia rather than fixed postures with contractures

Chorea

  • Definition - Unsustained rapid irregular non-patterned asymmetric movements that are purposeless. Most difficult to distinguish from cortical myoclonus. Typically, no urge and not suppressible.
  • On examination, ask patient to sit completely at rest, chorea is typically present distally in fingers and toes and increases with purposeful movement of involved body part.

  • Levetiracetam, Amantadine, Diazepam, Valproic Acid, Tetrabenazine and Neuroleptics (such as Risperdal) if severely disabling.

Sydenham chorea

  • Echo and EKG
  • Pencillin (or other abx)
    • Secondary prevention of GABHS to reduce the risk of future infections and cardiac involvement, typically until 40 years of age

Anti-chorea

  • Benzos
  • Keppra
  • VPA
  • Dopamine receptor blocking agents
  • Do not use anticholinergic as those can increase chorea

Immune modulatory in severe cases

  • Home treatment use po prednisone 2 mg/kg/day x 4 weeks with taper better than placebo
  • Inpatient treatment use IVIG or PLEX if incomplete response to IV steroids or contra-indication to steroids
